zoopedia_bamboo.text:
Only a few members of your zoo family, including the
giant panda
, the
red panda
, and the
gorilla
, enjoy this exotic treat, but it’s a crucial part of these animals’ diets.
Bamboo can be placed directly on the ground, or in an elevated food dish, browse holder, or trough.

zoopedia_bananas.text:
Bananas are a less popular food item among animals than you might expect. In fact, only the
chimpanzee
,
gorilla
, and the
ring-tailed lemur
can be counted among this fruit’s fans.
Bananas can be placed directly on the ground, or in an elevated or regular food dish. They can also be hidden in some containers to encourage exploring behavior in animals.

zoopedia_branches.text:
Branches are a fiber-packed component of several zoo animals’s diets, including
beavers
,
ostriches
,
chimpanzees
,
elephants
, and
moose.
A wide variety of animals also use branches as tools, toys, and sometimes even shelter. For example, baby animals may use a pile of branches as a cozy napping place, and male chimpanzees have been known to shake branches at females to get their attention.
Branches can be placed directly on the ground, or in a browse holder or elevated food dish.

zoopedia_fish.text: Fish is a staple in the diet of many zoo animals, including the big cats, bears, penguins, and crocodiles.

zoopedia_grass.text:
Like hay, grass is a primary food staple for grazing animals in your zoo, including the gemsbok, the kangaroo, and the rhino.
Grass can be placed directly on the ground, or in a trough, elevated food dish, or browse holder. Both the elevated food dish and the browse holder can be helpful for tall animals like the giraffe and the elephant.

zoopedia_hay.text:
Like grass, hay is a primary food staple for grazing animals in your zoo, including elephants, zebras, camels, and hippos.
Hay can be placed directly in the ground, or in a trough, elevated food dish, or browse holder. Both the elevated food dish and the browse holder can be helpful for tall animals like the giraffe and the elephant.
